context: Chapter 1.3 — Working alone in Maya's garage at midnight. Zero makes first contact through Echo.

lines.text: It's past midnight. Maya left hours ago — something about dinner with her mother, an apology she owed. You stayed behind. The Sakura's timing belt needs adjusting, and the silence of the garage is the only company you want right now.
Fluorescent lights hum overhead. The radio is off. Just you, the engine, and the smell of oil and brake dust. This is where the world makes sense.
Three knocks on the bay door. Precise. Even. Like someone counting time signatures.
You freeze. Nobody knocks on Torres Garage at midnight. Nobody who should be here, anyway.

You wipe your hands on a rag and walk to the side entrance. Through the smudged window, you see a figure standing perfectly still under the single streetlight. Tailored gray suit. Hands clasped in front. Patient in a way that suggests they would wait all night if necessary.
You open the door.
The figure is a woman. Mid-thirties, maybe older — impossible to tell. Her face is composed with surgical precision. No smile. No frown. Just observation.

lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: Good evening. I apologize for the hour. My employer prefers discretion over convenience.
She produces a card from her breast pocket. Matte black. No name, no number. Just a single symbol embossed in silver — a zero. The absence of a number. The beginning and the end.

lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: I represent an interested party. You've been noticed.

choices.text: I'm in the middle of something.
That card is supposed to impress me?

lines.label: echo_deflects
lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: Everyone asks that. No one gets an answer.

lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: I can tell you this: my employer watches the racing scene in Nova Pacifica the way an astronomer watches the sky. Not for what's there — but for what's about to arrive.

lines.label: echo_patient
lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: Of course. Timing belts don't adjust themselves.
She glances past you at the Sakura on the lift. Her eyes move across it with the practiced efficiency of someone who knows engines. She sees the car. She sees what it could be.

lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: Which is precisely why I'm here. You're working on a car that's beneath your talent. My employer would like to correct that imbalance.

lines.label: echo_amused
lines.text: Something flickers behind her eyes. Not offense. Something closer to... appreciation.

lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: The card isn't meant to impress. It's meant to inform. My employer doesn't need your admiration. They need your attention. For five minutes.

lines.label: echo_the_gift
lines.text: She steps aside and gestures toward the street. A flatbed truck is parked at the curb — you didn't even hear it arrive. On the bed, under a matte gray cover, is the unmistakable silhouette of a car. Something low. Something purposeful.

lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: A gift. No strings in the traditional sense. My employer believes in investing in potential. Consider it... a current.

lines.label: echo_philosophy
lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: My employer's philosophy is simple. Talent is a river. It flows whether you build a dam or not. The wise thing isn't to block it — it's to position yourself where the current is strongest.

lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: You are the current. This gift places my employer in your flow. Not as an obstacle. Not as a leash. As a presence.

lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: Win races. Lose races. It doesn't matter. What matters is that when the time comes — and it will — you remember who believed in you before anyone else did.
She lets the silence hang. Behind her, the covered car waits on the flatbed like a question you haven't answered yet.

choices.text: Take it back. I don't want it.

lines.label: echo_gravity
lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: Everyone asks that. No one gets an answer.
She says it exactly the same way as before. Same cadence. Same inflection. Like a recording.

lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: Think of it this way. You don't ask gravity who sent it. You simply acknowledge that it's the reason you're standing on solid ground. My employer is gravity. Invisible. Inevitable. Always pulling things toward their purpose.
That should sound ridiculous. It doesn't. Something about the way she says it — the absolute conviction — makes the hair on your arms stand up.

choices.text: Take it back. I earn what I drive.

lines.label: accept_gift
lines.text: Echo nods. One small, precise movement.

lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: A wise decision. The car will be unloaded within the hour. Keys are in the glovebox. Registration is clean — don't ask how.

lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: One more thing. My employer doesn't call. They don't text. They don't visit. When they need to communicate, you'll know. The message will find you the way water finds the lowest point.
She turns and walks to a black sedan parked behind the flatbed. No plates. Tinted windows. She opens the rear door, pauses, and looks back.

lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: Drive well. That's all that's ever been asked.
The sedan pulls away. The flatbed driver — a man you barely noticed — begins unloading the car. When the cover comes off, your breath catches.

It's beautiful. Not flashy — beautiful in the way a blade is beautiful. Every line serves a purpose. The paint is deep midnight blue, almost black, and the body kit is custom work you've never seen on any catalog. Whoever built this car didn't build it for show. They built it for someone specific.
They built it for you. And that thought should scare you more than it does.

lines.label: accept_morning
lines.text: Morning. You haven't slept. The new car sits in the garage bay like a panther in a birdcage. You've been staring at it for hours, running your hands over the engine, trying to understand what you've just agreed to.
The bay door rattles open. Maya walks in with two coffees and stops dead.

lines.speaker: Maya
lines.text: What the hell is that?
She sets both coffees down. Slowly. She walks around the car, touching nothing, seeing everything. Her eyes narrow.

lines.speaker: Maya
lines.text: Where did you get this? And don't lie to me.

choices.text: Someone sent it. A woman named Echo.
I bought it. Got a deal.

lines.label: maya_lie_response
lines.text: Maya stares at you. That stare that cuts through every layer of bullshit you've ever built.

lines.speaker: Maya
lines.text: This is a sixty-thousand-dollar car with custom work that would cost another forty. You didn't buy this. Try again.
You tell her the truth. All of it. Echo. The card. The speech about currents and gravity. Maya's face goes pale.

lines.label: maya_recognizes
lines.text: Maya picks up the matte black card from the workbench. She holds it like it might bite her.

lines.speaker: Maya
lines.text: I know this symbol. My dad got a card like this. Seven years ago.

lines.speaker: Maya
lines.text: He was the best mechanic in Nova Pacifica. Could make any engine sing. Then someone — someone with no name, no face — started sending him parts. High-end stuff. Prototypes. Things that hadn't even hit the black market yet.

lines.speaker: Maya
lines.text: He thought it was a gift. A patron of the craft, he called it. Built the fastest car this city has ever seen.

lines.speaker: Maya
lines.text: Then the favors started. Small ones at first. Fix this car, no questions. Store these parts, don't look inside. And by the time the favors got big, he was in too deep to say no.

lines.speaker: Maya
lines.text: He lost the shop. He lost his reputation. He lost... he lost a lot of things. All because someone gave him something for free and he was too proud to ask why.
She sets the card back down. Her hand is trembling.

lines.speaker: Maya
lines.text: That symbol is Zero. I don't know if it's a person or an organization or something else entirely. But I know what it does. It finds people with talent, gives them everything they need, and then owns them.

lines.speaker: Maya
lines.text: Please be careful. I can't watch that happen again.
She picks up her coffee, takes a long sip, and walks to the workbench. After a moment, she pulls on her gloves.

lines.speaker: Maya
lines.text: Well. We might as well see what's under the hood. If you're going to make a deal with the devil, at least let me make sure the devil gave you a good engine.
That's Maya. Scared, furious, and already reaching for a wrench. You don't deserve her.

lines.label: refuse_gift
lines.text: Echo blinks. Once. It's the first time she's shown any reaction at all, and it's small enough that you might have imagined it.

lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: You're refusing.
It's not a question. She's processing. Recalculating.

lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: May I ask why?

choices.text: If I don't know who's giving, I don't take.
Tell your boss to come say hello in person.

lines.label: echo_intrigued
lines.text: A pause. Longer than any pause she's allowed so far. Then — and you could swear this is the first genuine expression you've seen on her face — a flicker of something. Interest. Real interest.

lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: Intrigued.

lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: My employer has given gifts to eleven people in this city over the past decade. You are the first to refuse.

lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: I will relay your decision. I suspect it will be... well-received.
She tucks the card back into her pocket. The flatbed driver starts the engine. The covered car — whatever it was — disappears down the street like it was never there.

lines.speaker: Echo
lines.text: One last thing. Refusing the gift doesn't make you invisible. It makes you interesting. Whether that's better or worse... remains to be seen.

She gets into the black sedan. It pulls away without a sound. You stand in the doorway of the garage, heart pounding, oil still on your hands, and feel the weight of a choice you didn't fully understand.
You go back to the timing belt. Your hands are steady. The car you have is the car you earned. That has to be enough.
It is enough.
